item.title: Anand Rao Bhosle
item.description: Half brother of shivAjI. Able commander, who assisted svarAjya in several critical campaigns. Even acted as (unofficial) sarnobat for a while.

item.title: Bahirji Naik
item.description: Shivaji’s great spy, who led his master & the army thru secret mountain tracks known to him alone during the diler khan campaign.

item.title: bAji prabhu
item.description: bAji prabhu deshpANDe, a chandrasenIya kAyastha prabhu (dejure quasi-kShatriya dvija), who sacrificed his life at ghoD khiND delaying the enemy while ensuring shivAji’s escape. (Joke 1). His son Pilaji, who was taken Prisoner by the Sidi of Janjira and converted to Islam, reverted to Hinduism.

item.title: bALAjI vishvanAtha
item.description: bALAjI (=baLLAla = gaNesha) vishvanAtha (wiki, family tree), kauNDinya-gotra, peshva who overcame internal friction within marATha empire, won over kAnhoji Angre, consolidated shAhu’s position, subdued the mughal system. “Balaji convinced Shahu to alter Shivaji’s old constitution of the Maratha state, whereby the nobles were salaried employees of the ruler. Henceforth, nobles would be feudatories with grants of land over which they ruled as vassal princes.” “The Maratha tax collection system from a wide swathe of nominally Mughal provinces was based on a widespread network of agents and collectors.

item.title: Dhanaji Jadhav
item.description: (1650–1708), able commander, harassed the mughals.

item.title: dIpAmbA
item.description: dhArmika wife of ekoji the lesser half-brother of shivAjI, much admired by shivAjI for her personality and role during their interaction when he came down to tanjore to settle ekoji’s anti-svarAjya activities, who brought up her son shAhAjI the fine abhinavabhoja GGH who spread dhArmika activities in her realm - establishing agrahAra-s, settlement of Bhagavatamela artistes, facilitating pilgrimages, gathering scholars, sponsored dharmashAstra works such as tryambakamakhin’s strIdharmapaddhati and its marAThI translation Pativratadharma.

item.title: hambirrAv mohite
item.description: commander in chief of shivAjI and shambhu, father of Tarabai. - In early 1676, Hambirrao led a daring raid into Mughal territory as far as Bharuch in Gujarat & after much heroic fighting, brought back a large booty to the Raigad treasury. Later, during the karNATaka campaign, when shivAji had to rush back to raigarh, hambirrAv defeated Adil shAh armies and Ekoji. - During the attack on diler khAn and mogols while aiding Adil shAh - he saved shivAji’s trapped army and trounced diler’s army.

item.title: kAnhojI jEDhE deshmukh
item.description: deputed by Shahaji himself to protect shivAjI, who as a senior nobleman at a crucial juncture (during the Afzal Khan campaign) inspired and convinced all the deshkumkh-s to fight for svarAj rather than buckle towards Adil Shah, played major role in planning and executing battle of pratApgaD against Afzal Khan. - “Kanhoji Jedhe went to Rajgad with the firmans received from Afzal Khan and publicly declared that he would relinquish his lands and his earnings to Shivaji but not join Afzal Khan.

item.title: keLadi chennamma
item.description: keLadi chennamma, who provided refuge to rAjArAma and frustrated awrangzeb.

item.title: mAdanna akkanna
item.description: Intro madaNNa and akkaNNa, who protected the dharma as powerful ministers under qutub shAhis, collaborators with shivAji. “The family of mAdaNNA came from the town of Hanamkonda, Northeast of Bhaganagari, where under rudradeva kAkatIya a large temple of viShNu and sUrya had been constructed. The father of the brothers, bhANu-jI paNDita was a revenue administrator of the town and was named after one of the deities of the town. The son mAdhava paNDita (mAdaNNA) and arkarAja paNDita (akkaNNa) were also named after the two deities of the temple.

item.title: murAr bAji the kAyastha
item.description: who successfully defended purandara fort defiantly and with astounding energy despite superior enemy firepower and numbers [W].

item.title: Parshuram Tryambak Kinhaikar
item.description: (1660–1718 CE) / pant pratinidhi, an able general and administrator who assisted rAjArAm, tArAbAi, and later shAhu.

item.title: pratAprAv gujjar
item.description: a gifted general who defeated mogols at salher, made the mistake of releasing AdilshAhi general bahlol khan with troops and supplies at Nesari. shivAji scolded him in a letter, so he rode alone (followed by 6 others) in a suicide charge.

item.title: raghunAtha nArAyaNa hanmante
item.description: author of rAjavyavahArakosha (ref), who left the service of Tanjore’s Ekoji (aka vyAnkoji) Bhonsle to join his half-brother the brilliant shivAji, who counselled merciful quelling of ekoji’s despicable forwarding of muhammedan interests. He was made governor of the resulting southern conquests. He similarly publicly rebuked a wayward sambhAji.

item.title: rAjArAm
item.description: second son of shivAjI, who continued the struggle for svarAjya from Ginjee after Sambhaji’s murder, escaped to jinjI through keladi ruled by channamma, under whose reign the AjJNApatra was created.

item.title: rAmachandra panta
item.description: panta amAtya (1650–1716), the ably effected transition in times of trouble, who authored the AjJNApatra, who assisted shivAji, rAjArAm (as his regent when he was in flight), sambhAji, tArAbAyi, who instituted the “capture land from mughal-s, then own it” policy to encourage fightback, who adapted the policy of selling forts to the mughals (only to recapture them). He defeated the British march on puNe assisted by the traitor raghunAth rAv.

item.title: Santaji Mhaloji Ghorpade
item.description: (1660-1696) of the broader bhosale community, named by Shivaji on his death bed to be among six pillars of Maratha Empire, who in a daring feat cut the ropes of Aurangzeb’s tents and took the imperial golden pinnacles and fled boosting marATha morale and confidence, argued oft with rAjArAm over decisions and was sacked.

item.title: shAhu
item.description: shAhu kShatrapati, son of sAmbhAji, who bounced back from mughal captivity (and very poor education in his own religion [TW]) to take over the throne after defeating tArAbAyi, who was wise enough to let the most able men take power. Yet he sadly held bAjIrAv back when it came to completely uprooting the mogol empire[WP], held the mogol emperor in such regard and alleigence as to stop bAjIrAv from even constructing a gate facing north [TW].

item.title: shambhu
item.description: shambhAji, son of shivAji, who fought the siddi, Portuguese and mughals, who died rather than convert, [M1] who tried to induce a pan-Indian hindu unity against the yavana-s [M2 letter to rAmasimha] [battles 1680-1707 here]. - “Sambhaji was given to women and drink in the company of a brave but lazy Kanyakubja brahmin poet Kalash. .. Sambhaji remained lazy and missed a golden opportunity even as Awrangzeeb pressed home his fierce attacks on Bijapur and Golconda.

item.title: shivAjI शिवराजः
item.description: shiva/ shivAji kShatrapati (6 April 1627 or 19 Feb. 1630 – 3 April 1680) Impact यथान्यैरुक्तम् - नैकदुर्गविजेतारं धर्मकण्टकनाशनम्। शिवराजं वन्देऽहं खानोदरविदारकम्॥ प्रातिपश्चन्द्रलेखैव वर्धिष्णुर् विश्ववन्दिता। शाहसूनोश् शिवस्यैषा मुद्रा भद्राय राजते॥ कासिहू ते कला जाती मथुरा मसीद होती सिवाजी न होतो तौ सुनति होत सबकी - भूषणः। Brilliant concept under divine guidance, conceptualized and realized hindu svarAjya (evident even at a young age - see letter written to Dadaji Naras Prabhu at age 15 or 18 SG-academia), sought to rid hindusthAna of the mohammedan menace (letter to Jayasimha archive, P1 points 51 to 70, In south: “using the Qutbshah’s resources shivAjI conquered the fort of Gingee and extended his domain into the south ending the careers of several Jihadis and putting a check on the mlechCha-s who were surrounding the coast.

item.title: tArAbAyi
item.description: wife of rAjArAm, daugher of hambIr-rAv, who kept up the fight against the mughal-s. - She was later sidelined by a newly released shAhu and bAlAjI vishvanAtha. She propped up an impostor ( Rajaram II) and attempted various vain strategems - only to be foiled by bAlAjI. “On 14 September 1752, the two took oaths at Khandoba temple in Jejuri, promising mutual peace. At this oath ceremony, Tarabai also swore that Rajaram II was not her grandson, but an impostor from the Gondhali caste.
